Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP did not achieve compliance.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
A staff member attempted to place youth in an approved physical management due
to youth's aggression. It was alleged that staff placed youth in a hold and became
physically assaultive causing several scratches and bruising on youth's neck,
shoulder, side of rib cage, arms, and behind ear.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Foster Care Worker by phone on 3/29/2021. She reported already being
made aware of the allegations and that she is planning on visiting with Resident A later
today.
I interviewed Administrator 1 at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist
on 3/29/2021. He provided several documents including incident reports, policy/procedures
and face sheets on the residents that would be interviewed. He also provided Staff 1’s
personnel file for review which included his training history. He reported that Staff 1 has not
worked with Resident A since the incident took place.
I interviewed Resident A at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. He reports remembering the incident which began in the gym. He gave recall of
the incident.
It happened in the gym after I got into a fight with another kid. I was pissed that day. I
was sitting in the office with Staff 1 talking about what happened in the gym. He was not
processing the incident with me; he was just telling me I was going to get a consequence
for just getting into a fight. He was just trying to give me a consequence not trying to
deescalate me. I told him that I’m not afraid of anyone in this place and he said that if I
hit him, he would box me. He just kept trying to make everything my fault. So, I threw a
coffee pot on the floor and told Staff 1 to clean it up. It was glass and broke. Then I went
out and slammed the door behind me. Staff 1 came out of the office and said again that
if I hit him, we would box, and he started staring me down. I started hitting him and he
tried to restrain me. He also said “shit isn’t sweet around here”. A couple of times I
couldn’t breathe, and everything became a blur. At some point he took me to the ground
after pushing me up against the corner of the wall. While we slid to the ground, he had
his hands behind my neck. Once we were on the floor, I started headbutting him and this
is when Staff 2 started to help.
Resident A reported that Staff 2 “did not do anything he was not supposed to do”. He also
reported that Staff 2 told Staff 1 to “get him off the ground”. He stated, Staff 2 was present
throughout the whole restraint” and “Staff 2 was trying to deescalate me, but Staff 1 was
not”. Resident A reported that Supervisor 1, Resident B, Resident C, and Resident D all
witnessed the restraint noted in the allegations. Resident A reported “during the restraint I
started crying because I felt helpless, and Staff 1 said ‘oh shit you don’t get to cry now’”.
Resident A reports having no contact with Staff 1 since the incident, and he ended by
reporting that he feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Resident B at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. He reports being present during the restraint noted in the allegations. He stated,

I know Staff 1 and Resident A were in the office processing the earlier incident when I
heard glass break. Then I heard the door slam and a loud “fuck you”. This is when I
came out of the game room and saw Resident A trying to fight Staff 1. Both staff seemed
aggressive, but Staff 1 was using a lot more force with Resident A. Then Staff 1 pushed
Resident A against the wall and had his arm against Resident A’s neck, holding him
against the wall.
Resident B reported hearing Staff 1 tell Resident A he would box him. He also reported
hearing Staff 1 say to Resident A “why are you crying now” after Resident A began to cry
during the restraint. He reported hearing Staff 1 say “not the right staff to hit”. Resident B
reports that Staff 2 was “calming down Resident A” and “helped him stop being mad”.
Resident B ended by reporting that although he doesn’t like being in the program because
“they take privileges away for little things”, he still feels safe.
I interviewed Resident C at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. He reports remembering the restraint noted in the allegations. He stated, “I’m not
sure what happened” but I “saw a little bit of the restraint”. He also reported a belief that
Staff 1 antagonized Resident A, but he was unable to identify what he based this belief on
other than Resident A being very upset. Resident C gave the following description.
I heard the coffee thing break and when I looked, Staff 1 was restraining Resident A but
not in the right way. Staff 1 was being very aggressive and holding Resident A too tight.
Resident A said that he couldn’t breathe. Staff 2 tried to get in and pull Resident A away
from Staff 1.
Resident C ended by reporting that he has not seen Staff 1 since the incident and that he
feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Resident D at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. He reports remembering the restraint and was present for part of it. He gave the
following description.
Resident A broke a glass thing and came out of the office using curse words. Resident A
started hitting staff and Staff 1 started to restrain him. Staff 2 helped with the restraint.
I’ve never seen a restraint like that before. Staff 1 seemed very upset and was very
aggressive. He seemed to be mad that Resident A was hitting him. I heard Resident A
say he couldn’t breathe three to four times and just before they went to the floor. I also
heard Staff 1 say that he would do boxing on Resident A and Staff 1 told Resident A
don’t be crying now, when he started to cry.
Resident D reported that he observed marks on Resident A’s head when he saw him later.
Resident D ended by reporting that he feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. He reports remembering the restraint of Resident A and gave the following
description of the incident.
We went into the office to talk about what happened in the gym earlier. I was going to
process the incident with him, but he just started saying how he hates everything here. I
pointed out his behaviors are keeping him down and he responded by saying he doesn’t
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

want anyone to control him. I told him I’m not against trying to help him, but he stayed
focused on ‘tired of being here with these fucking kids’. He also said that he would shoot
anyone in the street if they confronted him and he made the symbol of a gun with his
fingers. I told him I’m done talking and that the shift supervisor will handle his
consequences for his behavior in the gym. He got upset over the idea of having
consequences and got up and pushed past me. The next thing I heard was glass
shattering at my feet and he stormed out of the office, slamming the door behind him.
Staff 1 reported that when he went out of the office, Resident A hit him on the left side of his
head with his fist. He also reported that Resident A was “outraged”, and Staff 2 tried to
restrain Resident A. He continued his recall of the incident once outside of the office.
He kept coming at me and I was trying to help Staff 2 restrain him. Resident A went for
my face and grabbed my nose. He even kicked me in my arm. We finally got him in a
two-person standing hold. Resident A said his neck or wrist hurt so I released his arm
and he swung at me again. He was headbutting me when we slid to the floor. We went
to the floor because Resident A dropped his weight. I had my arms over his arms and
not behind his head.
Staff 1 reported that he and Staff 2 were both talking to Resident A throughout the restraint
in an effort to deescalate him. He also admitted that he did say “you can’t hit me and cry
again”. He reported a belief that the restraint and Resident A’s acting out had nothing to do
with him. He did not recall hearing Resident A say he couldn’t breathe.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
3/29/2021. She reports being present for part of the restraint but that she was also involved
in supervision of other residents so she “didn’t see a lot of it”. She also reports being in the
kitchen “working on lunch” when she heard the glass break. She stated, “when I went to the
area, Staff 1 and Staff 2 had Resident A in a 2-person standing hold. Resident A started
headbutting them, so I put my hand up to block his head.” She reported that when Resident
A dropped his weight, Staff 2 let go but Staff 1 continued to hold him. She ended by
reporting overhearing Staff 1 say “you better not be starting that crying shit again”, which
she reported escalated Resident A. She stated, “at this point, Staff 2 took over and escorted
Resident A to his room”. She also stated, “Staff 1 tends to get into power struggles with
residents and doesn’t have a good relationship with them”.
I interviewed Staff 2 by phone in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on 3/29/2021.
He reports remembering the incident and that he was involved with other residents when he
heard glass break. He also reports that he observed “the office door being pushed open
really hard as Resident A came through it”. Staff 2 gave the following recall of the incident.
Resident A tried to slam the door on Staff 1 and when Staff 1 came out of the office,
Resident A began to punch him in the face. I got the other residents out of the area and
saw that Staff 1 dropped his keys on the floor. I picked up the keys and noticed that Staff
1 had Resident A in a 1-person standing hold with his arm on Resident A’s neck. I
moved his forearm from Resident A’s neck, and we moved to a 2-person standing hold.
Resident A dropped his weight and I let go of him. When Resident A stood back up, he
began to cry and that is when Staff 1 said ‘you can stop all that crying shit now”. This
statement only caused Resident A to become escalated again and he started punching
Staff 1 again. I got between them and took Resident A to his room.

Staff 2 reported that Staff 1’s use of his forearm on Resident A was not a correct behavior
management technique. He also reported a belief that Staff 1 “let what happened in the
office get to him”. He reports not hearing Staff 1 say he would box Resident A but being told
by Resident A that Staff 1 said “something like that”.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 by phone on 4/19/2021. She reports being the facility trainer
for the behavior management system. She provided copies of the techniques that are
approved for the use with residents. She reported that all staff were retrained on the
techniques on the Thursday prior to the Sunday incident that occurred. She also reported
being aware of the allegations and that the use of a forearm on the torso of a resident is a
prohibited technique and “should never be used”.
Documents reviewed:
Personnel file of Staff 1: I reviewed the personnel file of Staff 1 and the following
documentation was found. There was a “Growth Plan” dated 11/11/2020 which documented
the following.
Staff 1’s probationary period is scheduled to end on November 13th, 2020. During this
probationary period, the Home and Assistant Supervisor have engaged staff in several
coaching conversations. The coaching conversations focused on staff’s hesitancy or lack
of redirecting client and taking preventative actions to avoid or deescalate situation
which could lead to crisis.
This document also lists the “Action Plan” for improvement with Staff 1. The following
actions are to be accomplished by Staff 1 during his extended probationary period.
Staff will be expected to report to all shifts as scheduled. This includes any mandatory team
meetings or trainings.
Staff will be expected to develop a therapeutic rapport/relationship with all program
clients.
Staff will be expected to monitor client’s behavior and hold them accountable to the
program’s rules and expectations using established agency interventions.
Staff will be expected to demonstrate timely use of non-violent interventions through
verbal de-escalation. He will also be expected to engage in approved agency physical
management techniques when clients are in danger of harming themselves or others.
Staff will be expected to meet with Home and Assistant Supervisor weekly to discuss his
progress or issues related to this Growth Plan.
I reviewed a document titled “Probation Removal Letter” dated 1/8/21. This document
indicates that Staff 1 successfully completed his “extended probation period”. It states, “have
been evaluated and rated by your supervisor. You have been found competent to perform
the expectations of the position. As a result you are being removed from probation effective
1/8/21.”
Documentation of training hours was reviewed, and Staff 1 has completed 94 hours of
training over the past year. Documentation also indicates that he completed three hours of

 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

“Crisis Prevention & De-escalation training on 3/25/21 and scored a 100% on the final exam.
This same training is documented as being completed by Staff 1 on 11/7/2020 with the
same 100% final test score.
Incident Report. I reviewed the incident report for the allegations. This document is dated
3/28/21 and is identified as “Report # 10684”. This document is very similar to the reports
given by the staff and residents present. Prior to the physical intervention it is stated, “Staff 1
felt that the conversation was heading nowhere, so he told him, " I'm done. I am going to let
you talk to the shift supervisor, and he will discuss your consequences with you".” It noted in
this document that “At one point it appeared as if Staff 1 had Resident A in a choke hold.
Resident A was still being combative with Staff 1 and fighting off the attempted one person
EBR. Resident A kept going after Staff 1. It is also noted “The physical management was
ended at 1:25 pm. Client stood up and went to give Staff 2 a hug and started crying. Staff 1
said to client that he better not be doing that “crying shit now". Client escalated again and
attempted to attack Staff 1, but Staff 2 was able to step in between and help client de-
escalate and get client to his room to further de-escalate.”
Policy/Procedures. I reviewed the following policy/procedures:
Behavior Management Procedures 05-01 states “Whenever clinically advisable, staff
members are to first employ preventive and/or supportive behavior management
techniques, including a variety of de-escalation approaches and activation of client
self-control plans.”
Behavior Management Procedures Recommended Techniques 05-01.1 states
“Power of the Question: An emotional client can be unsafe to self/others. Ask a
question to enhance a cognitive response thereby increasing safety.”
Behavior Management Procedures Prohibited Techniques 05-01.2 states “Use of
profanity or sarcasm against a client. This method is considered morally
unacceptable and is counterproductive in a treatment setting.” “Excessive physical
restraint: During physical restraint, only as much force as is necessary to contain
aggressive behavior may be applied.”
Crisis Management Techniques 05-02 states “Wedgwood staff members are expected to
avoid the use of physical management whenever possible.”
Behavior Management Techniques. I reviewed the behavior management techniques that
staff are trained on. The facility uses the approved Aegis System for behavior management.
The description for the “Emergency Benevolent Restraint” is when the single staff moves
their arms in an effort to get behind the resident. There is no description of staff placing their
forearm on the chest or torso of the resident.
DHHS investigative pre-disposition call. The other DHHS investigator found a
preponderance of evidence to support that abuse/neglect occurred.

APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 1 Prohibition of Prone Restraint; Procedures Involving Other
Restraints in Child Caring Institutions
(2) Resident restraint must be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child's behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident's treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: Evidence provided through interviews and written documentation
support the allegations of Staff 1 not conducting the restraint in a safe
manner.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Repeat Violation – Special Investigation 2020C0128037 rule
violation 159.2 Resident Restraint with an approved CAP on
8/19/2020.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position
assigned.
ANALYSIS: The other DHHS investigator established a preponderance of
evidence to support that abuse/neglect occurred by Staff 1.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
